Massucco, Mr. Benito Rodriguez-Masso, PTO Lilliana Mendez and court interpreter Edna Brayfield. AUSA Massucco stated that due to defendant's circumstances, the government wouldn't oppose bail, but requested that the amount of bail be increased from what was recommended by PT, that defendant has to reside outside the housing project and that she's to receive treatment for her drug use problem. Mr. Rodriguez-Masso stated that he had to make arrangements with defendant's parents so that she could live with them outside the housing project. The Court granted bail in the amount of $20,000.00 cash or secured, she's to reside outside the Juana Matos Housing Project and is not to approach or enter the same, she's to secure employment, UA and outpatient treatment, plus all other standard conditions of release. (Court Reporter FTR.) (yr) (Entered: 10/31/2007)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Magistrate Judge Camille L. Velez-Rive :Arraignment as to Ramon Ocasio-Morales (19) Count 1,2,3,4,5,7 held on 11/5/2007. Present were AUSA G.A. Massucco, Mr. Rafael Anglada, PTO Angel Meaux and court interpreter Annie Flores. Mr. Anglada argued as to bail for this defendant, offering mother as 3rd party custodian and home incarceration with EM, but that there are no property or means to post bail. Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Camille L. Velez-Rive: Detention Hearing as to (27) Omar Rodriguez-Ortiz held on 2/19/2008. Present were AUSA Myriam Fernandez and Defense Counsel Jose Aguayo. The Government recommended bail higher of $25,000 and defendant be detained pending trial as he is a danger to the community. Defense Counsel rebut that defendant does not have prior criminal record, is not a flight of risk and his mother has a property that can be posted as bail. The Court adopted the recommendations of the PT services with certain modifications, imposing a bail of $25,000, home detention with electronic monitoring device, to study or work, to attend a an outpatient drug program and not to enter the Juana Matos Housing Project, all these in addition to the standard conditions. (CD Elba Rivas, PTS Angel Meaux, CI Annie Flores) (Court Reporter FTR.) (er) (Entered: 02/20/2008)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez: Appearing for the Government, Andrew Massucco and for defendant, Marlene Aponte. Defendant is present in Court.Arraignment and Bail Hearing as to Luis O. Perez- Gonzalez (23) Count 1,2,3,4,5,7 held on 3/4/2008. Defendant waived the reading of the indictment and enters a plea of not guilty as to all counts. Defendant is granted 5 days for discovery and 10 days thereafter to file any motions. The case is referred to Judge Fuste for trial setting. As to bail, defense counsel states that she has discuss the pretrial report with her client and even though she would request bail, her client has instructed her that he does not wish bail. Counsel for the Government is heard and requests detention. He further states that he does not agree with the pretrial report. The Court states that taking into account the statements made by both counsel and taking into account the pretrial recommendation, the Court finds that defendant is a risk of flight and a danger to the community and orders that defendant be detain pending trial. (Court Reporter FTR.) (mn) (Entered: 03/05/2008)

ORDER denying 2077 Motion for Reconsideration and to Appoint Counsel as to Luis A. Santiago-Cruz (21). See USSG Sec. 2D1(10)(D)(i1). Said guideline indicates that the two-level reduction provided in subdivision (1) of said section shall not apply in a case in which "the 2-level reduction results in a combined offense level that is less than the combined offense level that would apply if the offense involved only the other controlled substances." In your case, you pled guilty to a count involving different substances, to wit: Heroin, cocaine, marijuana, and crack cocaine, the equivalent of each was converted to marijuana and a base offense level of 32 was determined. However, taking only into consideration the amounts of heroin and cocaine involved, the same  base offense level would have been reached. Therefore, the requested two-point reduction is not applicable. Signed by Chief Judge Jose A Fuste on 3/9/2011. (mrj) (Entered: 03/09/2011)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Jose A Fuste:Final Hearing re Revocation of Supervised Release as to Miguel Melendez-Perez held on 10/17/2012. Present were AUSA Desiree Laborde and AFPD Sulay Rios and Carlos Vazquez. USPO Shakira Botello. The Court denied defendant's 2402 Motion for Discovery and 2403 Motion to Continue. However, def was granted time to review USPO's krono logs. The case was recalled once def finished reviewing such docs. Def counsel argued for defendant to be placed in impatient program rather than being revoked. After hearing arguments and reviewing krono's (marked as Court's Exh 1), the Court revoked defendant's SRT and sentenced him to IMPR- 36 MONTHS; SRT- NONE. (Court Reporter Amy Walker.)Hearing set for 09:30.Hearing held at 09:35.Hearing ended at 11:20.Interpreter Janis Palma. (gsr) (Entered: 10/17/2012)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Jose A Fuste: Final Hearing re Revocation of Supervised Release as to Jonathan Febre-Valcarcel (36) held on 11/5/2012. Present: AUSA Jenifer Rodriguez, Atty. Francisco Adams, USPO Orlando Rullan. Defendant is U/C and present in court. Arguments heard by all parties re facts of the alleged violation. After having heard the parties, the Court finds that the defendant violated his SRT and made a finding of Grade C violations. The defendant was sentenced to 3 months of IMPR and 92 months of SRT. Defendant was advised of his right to appeal. The Court advised the defendant that any further violation may entail his revocation for the statutory maximum term. (Court Reporter Amy Walker.)Hearing set for 09:30.Hearing held at 10:25.Hearing ended at 10:45 Interpreter Annie Navarro. (dv) (Entered: 11/05/2012)

Minute for proceedings held before Judge Jose A. Fuste: Final Hearing re Revocation of Supervised Release as to Juan C. Machado-Soto (37) held on 3/25/2014. Present: AUSA Olga Castellon, AFPD Hector L. Ramos-Vega, USPO Martin De Santiago. Defendant is U/C and present in court. Defendant was brought before this Court due to the fact that he is facing new criminal charges in state court. State cases are at a preliminary level. The Defendant is neither contesting nor admitting the alleged violations. Victims are present in court and are ready to testify. The Court made a finding of Grade A violations for the reasons that appear on the motions filed the USPO and determined that a sentence within the guideline doesn't afford adequate deterrence to criminal conduct. SRT was revoked. Defendant was sentenced to 36 months of IMPR to be served  consecutively to any pending case before the Bayamon Superior Court; no additional supervision. Defendant was advised of his right to appeal. (Court Reporter Amy Walker.)(Court Interpreter Felix Toledo.)Hearing set for 04:30.Hearing held at 05:38.Hearing ended at 05:51. (dv) (Entered: 03/28/2014)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Camille L. Velez- Rive:Show Cause Hearing as to Joseph Rodriguez-Martinez (42) held on 5/9/2014. Present were AUSA Olga Castellon, AFPD Vivianne Marrero and AFPD Leo Aldridge. Defendant was present and under custody. The Government called as their witness USPO Martin De Santiago. Direct and cross-examination conducted. AFPD Aldridge called to the witness stand PRPO Eli Manuel Rodriguez. Direct and cross-examination conducted. The Government presented its argument in favor of probable cause. AFPD Aldridge stated that defendant was not contesting the violation as to condition #2 - not reporting the arrest - but is contesting the violation to condition # 1 - new criminal conduct. After hearing the testimony of the witnesses and the arguments of the parties, the court found probable cause as to all violations included in the motion filed by  Probation and referred the matter to Judge Fuste for the full hearing. AFPD Marrero requested full discovery and the Court granted the request. (Court Reporter - FTR.)Hearing set for 09:00.Hearing held at 10:04.Hearing ended at 10:49. (yr) (Entered: 05/21/2014)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Jose A. Fuste: Final Hearing re Revocation of Supervised Release as to Joseph Rodriguez-Martinez (42) held on 6/3/2014. Present: AUSA Olga Castellon, AFPD Vivianne Marrero. Defendant is U/C and present in court. Defendant is not contesting violations #2 and #3. As to violation #1, defense counsel informed that state proceedings are still ongoing. Government stated that the agents are present to testify and the evidence is available for the court's consideration. Defendant waived his right to cross-examine the witnesses and accepted the proffer made by the government. Parties recommended a non-guideline sentence of 18 months. The Court made a finding of Grade B violations and sentenced the defendant to 36 months of IMPR to be served consecutively to any sentence that may be imposed at the state level; no additional supervision. Defendant was advised of his right to appeal. Defendant's request for a reconsideration was denied. (Court Reporter Amy Walker.)Hearing set for 09:30.Hearing held at 09:43.Hearing ended at 10:01.Interpreter Felix Toledo. (dv) (Entered: 06/05/2014)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Jose A. Fuste: Final Hearing re Revocation of Supervised Release as to Angel Rosa-Camacho (40) held on 12/16/2014. Present: AUSA Olga Castellon, AFPD Victor Gonzalez, USPO Martin Santiago. Defendant is U/C and present in court. After reviewing Dockets # 2659 Memorandum and Order and # 2663 Memorandum in support not to revoke, the Court will not revoke defendant's SRT at this time. The Court reprimanded the defendant and advised him that any other violation will entail a revocation. Defendant is not allowed to travel to Orlando. He shall remain in this jurisdiction. Government stated that the case agent is present in court to testify about the circumstances of the offense. The Court advised the defendant that he cannot have any contact with his consensual partner unless there is a clear order, with visitation rules, from a court with competent jurisdiction. If his consensual partner moves to Puerto Rico, they are not allowed to live together. The Court admonished the defendant and advised him that if there is any future violation he will be revoked. Defendant to be released. (Court Reporter Amy Walker.)Hearing set for 09:30.Hearing held at 09:58.Hearing ended at 10:12.Interpreter Janis Palma. (dv) (Entered: 12/16/2014)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Jose A. Fuste: Final Hearing re Revocation of Supervised Release as to Josue Rivera-Bruno (41) held on 2/27/2015. Present: AUSA Olga Castellon, AFPD Vivian I. Torralbas. Summons were issued. Defendant is present in court. Statements in support of mitigation of punishment heard on behalf of the defense. Defendant's allocution heard. Colloquy held between the Court and the defendant. After hearing the parties, the Court will not revoke defendant's SRT at this time. The Court reprimanded the defendant and advised him that any other violation will entail a revocation for the statutory period of incarceration. If defendant complies with the terms, the Court will consider recommending the transfer of his supervision to Pennsylvania. Defendant was ordered to comply with his supervised release conditions and to follow USPO's instructions. (Court Reporter Amy Walker.)Hearing set for 09:30.Hearing held at 10:00.Hearing ended at 10:14.Interpreter Felix Toledo. (dv) (Entered: 03/02/2015)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Camille L. Velez- Rive:Preliminary Revocation Hearing as to Josue Rivera-Bruno (41) held on 5/5/2015. Present were AUSA Olga Castellon and AFPD Vivian Torralbas. Defendant was present and under custody. AUSA Castellon requested a sidebar. Sidebar held. AUSA Castellon then informed the Court that Probation was withdrawing the 2710 motion as the case at the state level had been dismissed. The Court granted the request and the motion was deemed withdrawn as well as noting the informative motion filed by Probation. AFPD Torralbas requested that defendant be released under the same conditions of supervised release previously imposed. With no objection from the Government or from Probation, the Court granted the request and ordered defendant released under the same conditions of supervised release previously imposed. Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Jose A. Fuste: Final Hearing re  Revocation of Supervised Release as to Ronnie Rosa-Gordian (57) held on 2/19/2016. Present: AUSA Laura Montes, AFPD Giovanni Canino, USPO Ivelisse Alonso. Defendant was U/C, present in court and assisted by a certified court interpreter. Defendant accepted the alleged violations. ORDER: Denying 2888 "Motion for Early Termination" as to Josue Rivera-Bruno (41). As the Government states in the motion at Docket No. 2960 and the record reflects, during the year 2015 the USPO notified the Court of defendant's violation of supervised release conditions on two occasions (Docket Nos. 2685 and 2710). The fact that defendant has complied with the conditions for a little over a year is commendable, but compliance should be expected throughout the entirety of the term. Therefore, the Court finds that at this point the reasons expressed on the motion at docket 2888 are insufficient to grant early termination. Signed by Judge Pedro A. Delgado-Hernandez on 12/9/2016. (IFN) (Entered: 12/09/2016)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Pedro A. Delgado-Hernandez:Final Hearing re Revocation of Supervised Release as to Jorge A. Martinez-Arocho (48) held on 5/31/2019. Present: AUSA Edward Veronda, AFPD Vivian Torralbas and USPO Pabon. The defendant was present in court, O/B and assisted by the Court Interpreter. Defendant does not contest the alleged violations. After hearing the parties, the Court did not revoke the previously imposed SRT but modified it to include an additional condition: The defendant shall be placed in the location restriction program for a period of six (6) months and shall remain in his home during prescribed times in accordance with the Home Detention program. During this time, he shall remain in his place of residence, except for employment, substance/alcohol abuse treatment, employment, medical services or other activities approved in advance by the U.S. Probation Officer. Different location monitoring technologies are available and/or may become available under this program during the term of Supervision; those are to be selected by the Probation Officer in adherence to broad operational considerations for purposes of mitigating offender risks, providing supervision structure, and detecting various patterns of behavior. The defendant shall wear an electronic device twenty-four (24) hours a day and shall observe the rules specified by the U.S. Probation Office. Furthermore, the Court issued a stern warning to Mr. Martinez and ordered him to fully comply with his supervised release conditions and advised him that any future violations of his conditions could result in the immediate revocation of his supervised release term. The remaining conditions of supervised release remain in effect. All previous SRT conditions imposed on 11/6/2008 remain in effect (see Judgment at docket 1514 ). (Court Reporter Cindy Brown.)Hearing set for 10:30.Hearing held at 11:15.Hearing ended at 11:28.Interpreter Sonia Crescioni. (cc) (Entered: 06/05/2019)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Camille L. Velez- Rive:Preliminary Revocation Hearing as to Jorge A. Martinez-Arocho (48) held on 9/19/2019. Present were AUSA Kelly Zenon and AFPD Samantha Drake. Defendant was present and under custody. Waiver of preliminary hearing filed and approved. Probable cause found and the matter was referred to Judge Delgado-Hernandez for the full hearing. AFPD Drake requested to be heard on bail. The Court granted the request. Defense counsel argued for bail and ordered conditions of release, including continuing with the program he was participating. The Government opposed and argued against it stating the non-compliance by defendant with the EM requirements. After hearing both parties, the Court ordered defendant detained without bail. AFPD Drake requested reconsideration, which was denied. (Court Reporter -DCR.)Hearing set for 01:30.Hearing held at 02:20.Hearing ended at 02:29. Interpreter -Ani Navarro. (yr) (Entered: 09/27/2019)

JUDGMENT of USCA as to Luis A. Benitez-Serrano (16) entered on 05/05/2020; Petitioner Luis A. Benitez-Serrano seeks leave to file a second or successive 28 U.S.C. ｧ 2255 motion based on United States v. Davis, 139 S. Ct. 2319 (2019), and related precedent. It appearing that petitioner never pursued a first ｧ 2255 motion in the district court, leave from this court is unnecessary. Pursuant to Federal Rule of Appellate Procedure 22(a), petitioner's application is TRANSFERRED to the district court for docketing as a first ｧ 2255 motion. The motion shall be deemed filed in the district court on the date petitioner's second or successive application was filed in this court. The court expresses no opinion as to the viability or merits of the claim(s) set out in  petitioner's application. (x1) Modified on 5/7/2020 to correct name (xi). (Entered: 05/06/2020)

ORDER as to Jaime Agosto-Santana (51): In essence, the government opposes the USPO's request for early termination of supervised release because (a) defendant's crime demonstrates ability to place his interests above those of society and such conduct should not be rewarded with early termination of supervised release; (b) the term of supervised release adequately promotes deterrence of criminal conduct and provides protection of the community from further crimes of the nature that defendant committed; and (c) defendant received all potential benefits in this case through the consideration and approval of a plea agreement with the United States and in that sense, received the sentence that he bargained for (Docket No. 3535, p. 2). The government does not, however, analyze the elements that the USPO has put forth in support of its motion. The government should do so by October 30, 2020, including relevant caselaw and other sources of authority addressing the points that the USPO has referred to, to explain why those points do not warrant early termination of supervised release. Signed by Judge Pedro A. Delgado-Hernandez on 10/20/2020. (LMR) (Entered: 10/20/2020)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Pedro A. Delgado-Hernandez: Final Hearing re Revocation of Supervised Release as to Carlos I. Rosario-Gonzalez (47) held on 12/3/2020. Present: AUSA Mare Chattah, AFPD Cherrelle Herbert, and USPO Alexandra Castellanos. The record should reflect the proceedings are being held by VTC, given the emergency situation created by the COVID-19 pandemic. Therefore, the defendant has consented to proceed by VTC, and defendant has secured a waiver to that effect that appears on the record. The interpreter is acting and assisting the defendant via telephone. The defendant is present via VTC and we have a clear view of him on screen. After having heard the parties, the Court found that defendant violated the conditions of supervised release. Therefore, supervised release term was REVOKED. Sentence  imposed, IMPR: Three (3) months; No SRT to follow. The defendant was granted voluntary surrender by tomorrow, in coordination with the U.S. Probation Office. (Court Reporter Cindy Brown.) Hearing set for 09:30. Hearing held at 09:35. Hearing ended at 11:10. Interpreter Mary Jo Smith. (vso) (Entered: 12/03/2020)
JUDGMENT ON REVOCATION as to Carlos I. Rosario-Gonzalez (47), IMPR: Three (3) months; No SRT to follow. Signed by Judge Pedro A. Delgado-Hernandez on 12/3/2020. (vso) (Entered: 12/03/2020)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez: Initial Appearance re Revocation of Supervised Release as to Angel Cruz-Agosto (38) held on 3/11/2021. AUSA Linet Suarez and AFPD Victor Chico were present. Defendant was under custody, present and assisted by a certified court interpreter. All parties were present via VTC. Defendant voluntarily consented to the holding of the hearing via VTC. Defendant was advised of the alleged SRT violations filed at ECF No. 3409 and his right to a preliminary hearing to determine whether his supervised release conditions have been violated. The Court deemed it appropriate to appoint counsel. The FPD was appointed to represent the defendant. Defendant was ordered temporarily detained. A preliminary revocation hearing is set for 3/16/2021 at 9:30 am via VTC before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez. If the government intends to call a witness that is not fluent in the English language, failure of the government to timely retain the services of an interpreter may result in the imposition of sanctions. As required by Rule 5(f), the United States is ordered to produce all exculpatory evidence to the defendant pursuant to Brady v. Maryland and its progeny. Not doing so in a timely manner may result in sanctions, including exclusion of evidence, adverse jury instructions, dismissal of charges and contempt proceedings. (Court Reporter Zoom Recording.) Hearing set for 02:30. Hearing held at 02:52. Hearing ended at 03:02. Interpreter Ani Navarro. (jjr) (Entered: 03/12/2021)

ORDER: Denying 3611 "Motion to Reduce Sentence Pursuant to the Compassionate Release Statute 18 U.S.C. ｧ 3582(C)(1)(A)(1)" as to Luis Martinez-Serrano (9). The court has carefully examined the parties' motions and finds that defendant has not provided evidence to support his allegations that his alleged medical conditions make him especially vulnerable to COVID-19, especially when they seem to be adequately managed by the BOP and under control. He has not shown extraordinary and compelling reasons that would justify compassionate release. And because transfer to home confinement lies within the BOP's authority and discretion, the court will not entertain this request. With all this in mind, the court agrees with the government's position at Docket No. 3642. Signed by Judge Pedro A. Delgado-Hernandez on 4/19/2021. (MPL) (Entered: 04/19/2021)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Pedro A. Delgado-Hernandez: Final Hearing re Revocation of Supervised Release as to Felipe Colon-Marrero (50) held on 5/18/2021. Present: AUSA Jose Contreras, AFPD Victor Chico Luna, and USPO Ruben Velez. The defendant was present in the courtroom, under conditions of release, and was assisted by certified court interpreter. The parties agreed there were no contested facts as to the allegations made by the US Probation Officer. The Government argued that a Grade B violation is applicable in this case, highlighted defendant's reiterated violations,  and his decade-long drug addiction. Further, it argued that the appropriate sentence in this case is 12 months of imprisonment. Defense counsel argued for the application of a Grade C violation, and requested, if a finding is made as to the alleged offenses constituting a Grade B violation, that defendant be sentenced to time served followed by a term of supervised released focused on his rehabilitation. Allocution heard. The Court found that defendant violated the conditions of supervised release. Therefore, supervised release term was REVOKED. Sentence imposed- IMPR: Twelve (12) months; No supervision to follow. The Court ordered the defendant be remanded to the custody of the United States Marshal. (Court Reporter Cindy Brown.) Hearing set for 01:30. Hearing held at 01:30. Hearing ended at 02:11. Interpreter Ani Navarro. (vso) (Entered: 05/18/2021)
JUDGMENT ON REVOCATION as to Felipe Colon-Marrero (50), IMPR: Twelve (12) months; No supervision to follow. Signed by Judge Pedro A. Delgado-Hernandez on 5/18/2021. (vso) (Entered: 05/18/2021)

ORDER: Denying 3679 "Motion for Compassionate Release" as to Luis Cruz-Valcarcel (5). Defendant's basis for relief (he has served more than 65% of his sentence and his family in Puerto Rico needs him) does not raise to the level of extraordinary or compelling reasons to warrant compassionate release. Further, defendant is fully vaccinated for COVID-19. The court agrees with the government's position at Docket No. 3684. Signed by Judge Pedro A. Delgado-Hernandez on 6/17/2021.
